CSO anti-system movement character, binary: Works through legal channels, for the most part
CSO anti-system movement character, binary: Participates in elections
CSO anti-system movement character, binary: Works through a mix of legal and extra-legal channels
CSO anti-system movement character, binary: Insurrectionary

CSO anti-system movement character, binary: Democratic. Perceived by most disinterested observers as willing to play by the rules of the democratic game, willing to respect constitutional provisions or electoral outcomes, and willing to relinquish power (under democratic auspices)

CSO anti-system movement character, binary: Anti-democratic. Perceived by most disinterested observers as unwilling to play by the rules of the democratic game, not willing to respect constitutional provisions or electoral outcomes, and/or not willing to relinquish power (under democratic auspices)
CSO anti-system movement character, binary: Leftist, socialist, communist
CSO anti-system movement character, binary: Rightist, conservative, party of order
CSO anti-system movement character, binary: Ethnolinguistic, tribe, kinship, clan
CSO anti-system movement character, binary: Separatist or autonomist
CSO anti-system movement character, binary: Religious
CSO anti-system movement character, binary: Paramilitary
CSO anti-system movement character, binary: Heavily engaged in criminal activity, e.g., narcotics, bootlegging, illegal exploitation of natural resources, extortion, kidnapping
CSO anti-system movement character, count of expert ratings
CSO structure, binary: The state does not allow autonomous CSOs

CSO structure, binary: Large encompassing organizations dominate. The government and CSOs are linked formally through a corporatist system of interest intermediation; or, due to historical circumstances, particular large CSOs are highly influential. The voice of such organizations is recognized by the government and is accorded special weight by policymakers

CSO structure, binary: Neither large encompassing nor small CSOs dominate. Influence is contingent on circumstances. Organizations, both large and small, contend with one another to have their voice considered by policymakers
CSO structure, binary: Small CSOs dominate. Many small organizations contend with one another to have their voices heard by policymakers
CSO structure, count of expert ratings
